intro: Brassica campestris subsp. trilocularis, commonly known as the wild cabbage, is a perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with basal leaves that are lobed or entire. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. Its seeds are small and can remain viable in the soil for several years, contributing to its persistence in various habitats.
